seems about as reasonable

srcdata=""?
contents="" ?

so xml in xhtml, html in text/html

question is, in xml, do we want to require the <html xmlns="..."><head><title/></head><body> ... </body></html> boilerplate?
if we do, then it's going to be far less useful in xml
it's already less useful because XML escaping rules are ridiculous
(e.g. you must escape < in attribute values, iirc)
Could you theoretically put for instance SVG in there?
(not to mention that a stray U+FFFF would kill the whole page, etc)
i guess
what would the use case be?
I don't know, I haven't really followed the discussion :)
the main use case is for blog comments
which would mostly expect text/html, possibly with embedded svg or mathml
for text/html blogs anyway
so, if we allow the contents of a body element, only, would that be helpful in avoiding the xml/html choice?
xml/html choice?
it would affect what we call the attribute
don't think it would affect any xml/html issue
I mean: if we can avoid the need to put the boilerplate in and thus deal with xhtml or html the same way - is that possible?
xhtml and html are totally different
you can't treat them the same way
(however hard people insist on trying)
so i don't think the boilerplate issue affects that per se
what it affects is whether the attribute is really giving the contents of a document's <html:body>, or whether it's giving a full document
I see
so you would have a content-type attribute, too?
no, it would just be html in text/html docs, and xml in xml docs
oh! now I get it.
in that case I would not expect to have to repeat the boilerplate
(we don't want to require that non-web xhtml UAs have to include HTML parsers to be XHTML compliant)
just use @body , I'd say - it's an additional piece of body text to be displayed
yeah, body and srcbody are the main candidates i think
in fact, ppl might get the boilerplate wrong if they are required to repeat it - so that would avoid an additional source of errors IMO
(having "src" at the front is useful from a language usability point of view)
yeah, makes sense
makes it long, though, and people might think it's a URL
language design is hard :-P
yeah, I was just wondering about that
so much easier to reverse engineer mistakes other people have already made :-P
instead of having to make one's own
I know! Tell me about it! I've experimented with so many names for the time-aligned text stuff!
yeah! exactly
why not put an email out with your current state of mind and proposing @body and @srcbody and see what ppl say?

they just become big bikeshedding threads

hsivonen: so I've ported over George's jing issue-35 patch to the validator-nu branch, with some tweaks
MikeSmithX: awesome
I think I will have something ready to send you for review later today
ok
what I added was a way for it to distinguish between the case where a there is a choice among the missing attributes/elements, and the case where there's not
for the case where there's not, it emits a separate error message for each missing attribute/element
for the case where there's a choice, it emits, e.g., "Element object is missing one or more of the following attributes: data type."
I realize that for the case where there's only two attributes/elements in the choice, that doesn't make so much sense.
but I think there are other markup vocabs (DocBook, maybe) that have more complex choice cases than HTML does
as-is, what George's patch does is that it dumps out a text representation of the required content model
basically RNC syntax
but I think for most users that's probably not all that helpful
indeed
so I think the ambiguity of "missing one or more of" is an acceptable tradeoff vs. exposing end users to raw, potentially complex RNC content models
yeah
OK, anyway, I will try to get the patch wrapped up shortly
hsivonen: one thing I am not clear on is what the difference is in jing between the "required elements missing" case and what it calls the "unfinished element" case
IIRC, unfinished element is a special case of the former
but in the v.nu message-emitter, I can see that both cases basically cause the same message to be emitted
hsivonen: OK
for our purposes, it seems like the can be handled the same
MikeSmithX: I don't really know why Jing makes the distinction
OK

my thinking is that text/html vs. application/xhtml+xml choice should affect the hop from server to DOM
but making various other things change behavior, too, doesn't maintain clean layering in theory and in practice makes it harder to change the hop from server to DOM

hsivonen: that is a plausible view - but there are DOM APIs that differ which we aren't really free to change, so it seems more valuable to me to keep markup syntax consistency within each serialization
hsivonen: I wish there were separate APIs for interacting via HTML and XML serializations, so you could pick one explicitly instead of it being based on your MIME type

i don't understand why the "applicable specifications" stuff is so hard for people to understand
it's just a description of what has always been the case
did people just not realise that's what was going on?
People seem to think it is magic for some reason
most specs do not explicitly allow that other specs can modify them
But all specs can effectively be modified by other specs
the people who are finicky about such things made Modularization
the people who are not just went ahead and defined ad-hoc extension specs without permission from the spec being extended
HTTP isn't "modular" but people extended that and nobody seems to have a problem with the concept
They have a problem with the concept if you tell them about it
it's like half the standards community is living in an orwellian "doublethink" world
I think it's explicitly acknowledging the potential for add-on extensions without formally defining an extension point as such that bothers people
though I'm not even sure it's fair to say that

I think there is this idea that either there needs to be a central authority declaring which specs are applicable, or an open-ended extension mechanism where some sort of distributed namespacing allows people to invent extensions with no coordination at all

Is it intentional that the discussion about "drawfocus()" seems to be talking about something quite different to the spec's drawFocusRing()?
since the latter is meant to be something you call for every element that you draw, regardless of whether it's focused or not, and it will only draw if the element is focused
but people seem to be talking about some kind of method that you only call on focused elements, or on elements that you want to become focused

The dataTransfer being 'Empty' on dragenter and dragover is a security feature. It doesn't even expose the set of mime types of dragged files. How can a page decide whether or not it can accept the drop? Is exposing of mime type a risk?

Hixie, re: using HTTP URLs for Microdata itemtype, does it have to be a URL at all? http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-January/024770.html
The problem I have with using URLs for this, and for namespaces in general, is that formats will most likely out-last the organisation that created them and assigned the namespace or itemtype URL
